Merge pull request #584 from StackStorm/STORM-444/history

Add sort to REST API for action execution history

Add sort to REST API for action execution history

The default sort order for the history records is by descending order of
the execution start_timestamp.
http://localhost:9101/history/executions

The placement of the datetimes in a range query determine the sort order automatically.
http://localhost:9101/history/executions?timestamp=20141225T000010..20141225T000019
http://localhost:9101/history/executions?timestamp=20141225T000019..20141225T000010

The sort order can be overridden by a query param named "sort".
http://localhost:9101/history/executions?sort=action,timestamp

The sort direction can be changed to descending by prepending '-'.
http://localhost:9101/history/executions?sort=action,-timestamp

http://localhost:9101/history/executions?action=local&user=system

http://localhost:9101/history/executions/123abc456def789abc123def

Merge pull request #550 from StackStorm/STORM-8/user-auth

Push get of auth token from env to the py client
Push get of auth token from env to the py client

Handle rabbitmq connection closes with retries
  Refer: https://github.com/celery/kombu/commit/1c5f0ecf9f79e0c3f8f689057541295d3bf7a336#diff-9fa13492ded708799168a1c48c81584cR104
  * Fabric uses multiprocessing for running tasks in parallel. Kombu
    wants to reset connections on multiprocessing forks. So you
    see abrupt rabbitmq channel closes. There also seems to be
    a bug in connection status not being synced to channel
    status in Kombu.
  * Fix: Add retries to publish loop and call ensure_connection
    to make sure connection can be re-established. This is needed
    anyways. It just happens to be a work around for the above bug.

Merge pull request #508 from StackStorm/STORM-8/user-auth

SSL support in CLI

SSL support in CLI

By default, auth endpoint is configured to use https if not overridden
in CLI argument --auth-url or environment variable ST2_AUTH_URL. A
cacert option is added as CLI argument --cacert and environment variable
ST2_CACERT. If cacert is provided, HTTPS requests will set to verify.
The cacert option is ignored for regular HTTP requests.

Merge pull request #261 from StackStorm/STORM-299/content-registration

[STORM-299] Content Structure and Location

[STORM-299] Content Structure and Location

Clean up project folder structure for contents such as sensors,
triggers, rules, and actions. The following describe the changes. Repo
structure is defined and configurable via appropriate config file. Start
script for each service will create the high level paths (i.e.
/opt/stackstorm/sensors) defined in their config file as part of the startup sequence.

Repo Structure
The following is the file system structure for the repo regardless of
system vs. user generated contents.
./sensors -> sensor plugins
./sensors/webhooks -> custom webhooks and schema
./sensors/schedules -> timer schedules
./sensors/triggers -> additional triggers in JSON files to be registered
outside of sensors
./rules -> rules in JSON files to be registered
./actions -> action plugins and the JSON files required for the action
plugins to be registered

Repo Locations
Each repo location listed below is expected to have the same underlying
structure defined above in the "Repo Structure" section.
/opt/stackstorm -> Default location for user generated contents on
product installation. The content folder is removed from the path to
make this more simple (i.e. /opt/stackstorm/sensors,
/opt/stackstorm/rules, etc.).
stanley/contrib/core -> Location in the github repo for St2 contents
that will be shipped with the product.  These contents will be copied
over to /opt/stackstorm on install and then auto-registered.  We expect
users to be able to edit these contents post install.  The use of the
name "core" represent that this is a set of core contents that it's
valuable to be shipped and installed with the product.  Alternate name
is "base" for base contents or basic contents.
stanley/contrib/examples -> Location in the github repo for St2 samples
that may be of interest to the users.  These samples will be shipped
with the product but will not be auto-registered.
stanley/contrib/sandbox/packages/<SomePackageName> -> Location in the
github repo for self contained packages that we are developing (i.e.
correlation).  The <SomePackageName> is a directory with an arbitrary
name we give for the package. The structure should the same as a normal
repo structure with sensors, rules, and actions directories.  These
packages will not be shipped with the product.
stanley/contrib/sandbox/scripts -> Location in the github repo for any
scripts and tools for development purposes.

Merge pull request #216 from StackStorm/STORM-275/launch-script-for-dev

[STORM 275] Create launch script for development

[STORM 275] Create launch script for development

Created a launch script for development environment that starts/stops all API servers in detached screen sessions. The launch script will automatically install screen if it's not installed. The script will also reasonably try to determine where the stanley repo is located assuming this script has not been relocated and separated from the stanley repo.

Assuming /home/vagrant/stanley is the directory where the stanley repo is clone. The following are example usages.

cd ~/stanley/devel/scripts
./launch.sh start
./launch.sh stop
cd ~/stanley
./devel/scripts/launch.sh start
./devel/scripts/launch.sh stop
cd ~
~/stanley/devel/scripts/launch.sh start
~/stanley/devel/scripts/launch.sh stop
cd /

[STORM-175] Basic CLI - Support resource update

[STORM-175] Basic CLI - Support resource update

Added support to allow update of resource types such as action and
rule. The update command requires resource ID and the modified JSON file as arguments. Since ID is provided in the argument, ID is not required in the JSON file for the update. However, if there is an ID in the JSON file and it does not match with the ID provided in the argument then an exception will be thrown.

Example:
st2 rule update 96f111045f65427cbff062f217c96f10 myrule.json

[STORM-73] Use Audit level for logging

Implemented a common logger in st2common with new AUDIT level and audit
function. Included unit tests for logging info and audit messages. A
sample logging.conf is included under tests/resources that shows how to
configure audit handler and is used by the unit tests. Refactored st2 to
use the new log module.

Example: (Please note that the logging.setup only has to be invoked once
in the main program.)

    from st2common import log as logging
    logging.setup(config_file)
    LOG = logging.getLogger(log_name)
    LOG.audit('Anything that can go wrong will go wrong.')

Closes: STORM-73
